6.heading: Blame.

notes: Summary: Everybody blames lawyers, who in turn blame doctors, but who does the doctor blame?

7.heading: Blame.
7.title: "Golf Would Be a Whole Lot More Enjoyable if you had Teammates to Blame the Bad Shots On"
7.author: by Jeff MacNelly.
notes: Summary: Skyler is talking, and Cosmo's ball is up in a tree.

8.heading: Blame.
8.title: "He's Not Quite That Bad, Martha"
8.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The lawn chair business is working, and Amos gives Martha $15. The last time Martha got money from Amos was when she took the blame for his sitting on her father's ukulele.

9.heading: Blame.
9.title: "L'Homme des Montagnes Bleues"
9.author: [No author]
9.series: Giddap Joe) p. 99-130 in Cap'tain Swing, no. 114
notes: Summary: The story opens at "Terre Brulée," the ranch of Giddap Joe. An Indian boy named Wa Wa is hauling water for the horses when he comes upon White Deer, a girl who brings a warning. The white man in the blue mountains must leave, she says, or he will be killed. There are only 15 days until winter snow is expected. Joe takes the warning seriously, and rides up into the mountains to look for the man. The man turns out to be Bruce Altman, an old friend. It starts to snow early, and the two are stuck in Altman's cabin for the winter. Altman's story is that he was out hunting with his young son Tom, six years earlier, when Tom saw an Indian, panicked, and killed her. She was out picking berries. Bruce told Tom never to admit he did it, and Bruce took the blame for the crime himself. The incident led to the killing of two other white families by the Indians. The people of the town, Lone Pine, were about to lynch Bruce as the cause of the Indian attacks, so he went into hiding. Unbeknownst to Bruce, Tom has stood up in church and told the truth within the past year, to clear his father's name. The brother of the dead girl is still hunting Bruce, but Giddap intercedes and explains the situation to the brother. Bruce goes home.

10.heading: Blame.
10.title: "I Blame My Brain"
10.author: Michael Jantze.
notes: Key words: Nightclubs, discos, women as objects, coffeehouses, women as people, congratulations.

11.heading: Blame.
11.title: "It Ain't Rocket Science, Maggie!"
11.author: M
notes: Summary: Fergus ate Maggie's math homework, and Fergus blames her, saying you don't just leave homework in front of a dog.

12.heading: Blame.
12.title: "It's Not My Fault"
12.author: by William Wells & Jack Lindstrom.
notes: Summary: The reporter at the New York Stock Exchange begins her report.

13.heading: Blame.
13.title: Lap Dancing for Mommy : Tender Stories of Disgust, Blame and Inspiration
13.author: by Erika Lopez.

14.heading: Blame.
14.title: "Mom, I Want Your Advice on Something Important"
14.author: Scott and Borgman.
notes: Summary: Jeremy asks for advice, but reserves the right to disrespect it, and when she decides not to give him the advice under his conditions he wonders if she'll take the blame if he decides badly.

15.heading: Blame.
15.title: "Near Calamity"
15.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Pat Owen comes out of the drugstore and we hear a wolf whistle; it's the peanut vendor, but Lard almost gets blamed and drummed out of the corps: It's still Woman-Hating Week.

16.heading: Blame.
16.title: "No One Would Blame You If You Just Had Him Put Down"
16.author: Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: The doctor is talking to the wife of the patient; all three are dogs.

17.heading: Blame.
17.title: "Now I Understand the True Meaning of, 'The Fastest Way to a Man's Heart'"
17.author: Armstrong.
notes: Summary: Joe's mom blames herself for her husband's heart attack, saying she could have controlled his diet.

18.heading: Blame.
18.title: "Oh, Sure! Blame Me!"
18.author: by Jim Davis.
notes: Summary: Everything in the house is chopped up, and Jon yells at Garfield, who's standing there with a hatchet.

20.heading: Blame.
20.title: "Slaine, the Horned God"
20.author: story, Pat Mills ; art, Simon Bisley
20.appears_in: p. 10-69 in Heavy Metal, v. 14, no. 6 (Jan. 1991).
notes: Summary: Slaine enters the Cauldron of Blood to talk to the Earth goddess. He learns about the nature of matriarchy and the role of the male gods in it. Then Medb summons Avagdu from the cauldron to kill Niamh, and when he fails, Niamh blames the attack on Slaine.

162.heading: Blanchenoud, Victor.
162.title: "La Route des Goëlands"
162.author: scénario, Sylli ; dessins, Ab Aigre.
notes: Summary from contents page of no. 35: Anyline tries, at the request of her mother, to find her father. She leaves the Antilles and goes to Lausanne, where a museum is showing the works of Victor Blanchenoud, an artist who has been locked up for years.

163.heading: Blanchenoud, Victor.
163.title: "La Route des Goëlands"
163.author: scénario, Sylli ; dessins, Ab Aigre.
notes: Summary from contents page of no. 36: The mystery around the life and death of Victor Blanchenoud deepens with strange events: the arrest of a crazy man, the theft of a statue. The intervention of journalist R. Netz prompts Anyline to pursue her own investigation.

164.heading: Blanchenoud, Victor.
164.title: "La Route des Goëlands"
164.author: scénario, Sylli ; dessins, Ab Aigre.
notes: Summary from contents page of no. 37: Anyline finds the journal of her father, Victor Blanchenoud. This tells the story of his meeting with Cerisier, the painter, and Manuia, the native faithful to the charm and menace of the Tiki.

165.heading: Blanchenoud, Victor.
165.title: "La Route des Goëlands"
165.author: scénario, Sylli ; dessins, Ab Aigre.
notes: Summary from contents page of no. 38: The story of Blanchenoud shows us his return to Switzerland, the relations of his wife with Von Glütz, the end of his sanity. Despite his struggle to preserve his rights, he feels imprisoned by evil; science may prefer to believe in folly and ignore the Tiki...

166.heading: Blanchenoud, Victor.
166.title: "La Route des Goëlands"
166.author: scénario, Sylli ; dessins, Ab Aigre.
notes: Summary from contents page of no. 39: Accused of murder and locked up as insane, Blanchenoud spends his time making statues. Strangely, they recall the double curse of the Tiki.

167.heading: Blanchet, Evariste.
167.title: "Cance/Guillot : Regards Croisés sur un Demi-Siècle de Bédéphilie"
167.author: Évariste Blanchet
167.appears_in: p. 8-15 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 9 (Oct. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Hop! et Le Collectionneur de Bandes dessinéws (CBD) atteindront d'ici quelques mois leur centième numéro, un record qu'aucune publication spécialisée n'avait jamais atteint jusqu'ici. Du moins en France, puisque le Comics Journal américain a dépassé le 200e numéro et le Stripschrift hollandais le 300e. C'était l'occasion de réaliser un entretien avec leurs animateurs principaux, respectivement Louis Cance et Claude Guillot, sur le thème de la bédéphilie et les collectionneurs, bien que ni l'un ni l'autre ne se considèrent comme tels. Ils ont été interrogés séparément, le premier en décembre 2002, le second en février 2003. Nous n'avons pas retranscrit les questions."

English summary (from p. 126): "A Two-Way Look at Half a Century of Comics Collecting: Two French publications specialized in the study of old comics, Hop! and Le Collectionneur de Bandes Dessinées, are approaching the hundred issues mark. For this occasion, Evariste Blanchet has interviewed their editors, Louis Cance and Claude Guillot, on the history of the magazines and on the theme of comics lovers and collectors in general."

168.heading: Blanchet, Evariste.

168.author: Evariste Blanchet
168.appears_in: p. 142 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 5 (Jan. 2000).
notes: Review of Transperceneige (later titled L'Échappée) (Jean-Marc Rochette & Lob) ; and "L'Arpenteur" (Rochette & Benjamin Legrand)

172.heading: Blanchet, Évariste.
172.title: "Marche ou Rêve"

notes: Review of Ciboire de Criss! (Julie Doucet).

173.heading: Blanchet, Evariste.
173.title: "Par Tout Hotis"
173.author: Evariste Blanchet
173.appears_in: p. 137 in 9e Art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 8 (Jan. 2003).

174.heading: Blanchet, Evariste.
174.title: "Pirates!"
174.author: Evariste Blanchet
174.appears_in: p. 100-105 in 9e Art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 8 (Jan. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Les pirates dévastent les systèmes informatiques les mieux verrouillés, rôdent dans nos rues insécurisées (d'où la nécessité d'un plan 'Vigipirates') et abordent la culture avec, au printemps dernier, un salon du livre alternatif baptisé 'Littératures Pirates', à l'initiative des éditions Amok. Omniprésents, ils n'en finissent pas de voguer dans notre imaginaire. Des pirates de tout sort, de toute époque et de tout lieu ont également sillonné la bande dessinée."

English summary (from p. 151): "Pirates! If Barbe-Rouge by Charler and Hubinon represents the classic reference for pirate stories in French-Belgian comics, it is interesting to compare it, as Evariste Blanchet does, with recent creations such as Petrus Barbygère (by Sfar and Dubois), Kaarib (by Calvi and Krassinsky), and of course the startling Isaac the Pirate (by Christopher Blain), which is full of surprising characters, among which stands out that of Alice, a magnificent portrait of a woman."

187.heading: Blanco, Caridad.
187.title: "Ares : An Undomesticated Humorist"
187.author: Cardid Blanco de la Cruz ; translated from Spanish by Gisela Gil-Egui
187.appears_in: p. 106-115 in International Journal of Comic Art, v. 3, no. 2 (Fall 2001).
notes: Ares is Cuban cartoonist Arístides Hernández (1963-).

188.heading: Blanco, Caridad.
188.title: "Cuadros"
188.author: Caridad Blanco de la Cruz
188.appears_in: p. 31-45 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 1, no. 1 (Abril 2001).
notes: Resumen: "Cuadros es una propuesta de recorrido por la historia de la historieta cubana; un modo de ensartar un grupo considerable de los fragmentos imprescindibles para reconstruirla desde una actualidad en la que muchas veces se pierden de vista los elementos puntuales que han sostenido y desarrollado a la narrativa dibujada como una de las expresiones de las artes visuales en Cuba."

Abstract: Cuadros (squares) is a recurring proposition throughout the history of Cuban comics. This is an attempt to link a group of essential fragments, a way to rebuild history retrospectively, a history which has lost sight, in many cases, of elements that have supported and developed the drawn narrative as one of the expressions of the visual arts in Cuba.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.

189.heading: Blanco, Caridad.
189.title: "The Engineering of Humor"
189.author: Caridad Blanco de la Cruz ; translated from Spanish by Gisela Gil-Egui
189.appears_in: p. 191-194 in International Journal of Comic Art, v. 1, no. 2 (Fall 1999).
notes: About Cuban cartoonist Lázaro Fernández Moreno, born in 1935, who signs his work Lázaro.

190.heading: Blanco, Caridad.
190.title: "Salomón, un Mutante Perturbador"
190.author: Caridad Blanco de la Cruz
190.appears_in: p. 108-118 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 1, no. 2 (Junio 2001).
notes: Resumen: "'Salomón' está considerado por los creadores gráficos del pais como el personaje que innovó el lenguaje humoristico de la historieta cubana por toda su carga filosófica, existencial y humanista. Santiago Armada (Chago: 1937-1995), su creador, es también considerado un artista que desdeñó las clasificaciones y motivaciones epidérmicas en el género. La relación obra-autor es analizada en este breve ensayo."

Abstract: 'Salomón' is considered by graphics creators as the character that initiated the language of humorous Cuban comics, with all its philosophical, existential and humanistic content. Santiago Armada (Chago: 1937-1995), his creator, is also considered to be an artist who disdained the classifications and shallow expectations of the genre. The relationship between the work and its author is analysed in this brief essay.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.
